author: bridge-bot
content:
<ranchalp> I wanted to share a write-up on rollups and their trade-offs. While rollups improve scalability with higher throughput and lower costs, they don’t reduce latency at Ethereum L1-level security. Faster-than-Ethereum latencies come with risks like double spends, and it’s important we address these transparently.
Would love to hear your thoughts! Full write-up here: https://hackmd.io/HjhzbAu3SkGsNW_Q3-veJg?both.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<OhadStarkWare> hey @ranchalp  a real interesting piece that indeed show-cases a real issue. I want to offer another potential mitigation which we consider whether to include within Starknet decentralization - have proofs for consensus available relatively soon after a block is finalized (probably order of magnitude slower than block-time on SN, but also multiple orders of magnitude faster than L1 finality).

People that are afraid from this kind of attack can wait until tx reaches this status and then immediately submit the state on L1 (its not a perfect mitigation - because there could be a race condition here with a malicious revert, but nonetheless could be a worthwhile direction to explore) (re @ranchalp: I wanted to share a write-up on rollups and their trade-offs.
